Authors:
Sita Preedanon, Anupong Klaysuban, Satinee Suetrong,
Pitchaya Kedkaew, Waratthaya Promchoo, Wunna Gundool, Tanuwong
Sangtiean, Jariya Sakayaroj
Title:
Lautosporales ord. nov., a novel order of mangrove
ascomycetes in the Sordariomycetes.
Keywords:
Lautospora obovoidiella sp. nov., Lautosporales, marine
fungi, Sordariomycetes
Abstract:
A new species of a genus Lautospora, L. obovoidiella sp.
nov., was described from dead intertidal mangrove wood in southern
Thailand. Morphologically, L. obovoidiella is characterized by having
immersed ellipsoidal ascomata, unitunicate cylindrical asci, obovoid and
thick-walled ascospore. Its morphological features are resemble to the
other species of Lautospora, L. simillima and L. gigantea, but differ in
ascospore shape by rather round at the apical region and elongate at an
ascospore base. A genus Lautospora was originally classified in the
Lautosporaceae by Kohmeyer et al. (1995). The multi-gene molecular data
of small subunit (SSU), large subunit (LSU) ribosomal DNA, the
translation elongation factor 1-alpha gene (TEF-1α) and the RNA
polymerase II gene (RPB2) confirmed the taxonomic position of this
fungus. The result reveals that L. obovoidiella forms a well-supported
clade with the two Lautospora species within the Lautosporaceae.
Additionally, L. obovoidiella strains constitute a separate group within
the Lautospora spp. subclade with strong statistical supports. Based on
the unique morphological and molecular evidence, a new marine fungus L.
obovoidiella is proposed. Interestingly, the Lautosporaceae forms a
highly supported monophyletic clade without any named orders in the
Sordariomycetes. Therefore, a new order, Lautosporales ord. nov., is
also proposed.
